Now that hydras are making a name for themselves as the iconic big green monsters, they have a lot of ground to cover to catch up with the likes of dragons, demons, and angels in terms of establishing an identity as a major tribe.  This is the first card that references the hydra lifecycle by including "baby" hydra tokens.

380439: Hypnotic Siren.author: Tamerlein
380439: Hypnotic Siren.text_parsed:
Guys, you don't understand. This card is not constructed playable at all whatsoever. Even if mono blue devotion wasn't dieing off anyway, this card would not help that deck at all. A 1/1 flyer for one only works if it has some very strong upside, like Judge's Familiar and Cloudfin Raptor. As long as those cards are Standard legal, no competitive Standard player worth his salt is going to touch the Siren.

Here's the deal: seven mana is way too much in order to take control of an opponent's creature, even if it gives it +1/+1 and flying and you get a 1/1 flyer after it dies. It just isn't strong enough an effect for seven mana (don't you dare compare this with the powerhouse that is Sower of temptation). Mono blue devotion usually curves out at four, maaaaaaybe five with the occasional sideboard card. A few decks stretch to six with an Aetherling on sideboard, but a lot of people would say that that is a bad decision. Even then, in terms of raw power, Aetherling is the most powerful blue finisher in Standard right now. Do you really think that this guy is even close to being as powerful as him? The same goes for Esper Control. While it is true that they have seven mana on a regular basis, Elspeth, Sun's Champion and Aetherling are much better finishers.

This is fine in limited, though. Because in the current limited environment a lot of times your opponent will be beating you down with one giant dude that has a lot of bestowed creatures on him, being able to take control of that creature without allowing your opponent to get all of his bestowed creatures is very nice.

380439: Hypnotic Siren.author: DaLucaray
380439: Hypnotic Siren.text_parsed:
RAV004, let me explain to you the difference between this and Sower of Temptation.

For starters, this gives your stolen creature flying. Sower does not. Then there's the fact those two cards act completely differently to removal. Our Faerie friend dies to any removal spell worth it's salt, from red's burn to black's destroy to white's exile- even green's flyer hate. Then your opponent gets a creature back and you're down a fae. With the super Siren, however, your opponent has to kill the opposing creature if all he or she has is a kill spell Then they lose a creature and you still get a Flying Men. In a slower game that's definitely worth tree mana.

Then add the fact you can use the siren turn one or two if you fell it's necessary.

They're both good cards and are both priced well for what they do.

380441: Iroas, God of Victory.author: CautionFireLizards
380441: Iroas, God of Victory.text_parsed: Not a Centaur - can tell by looking at the tail, which is clearly a bull's and not a horse's. This set up - with a bull's body and a human's torso and head - was actually the more popular way to depict the classic Minotaur in Italian Renaissance art. For example, the Minotaur in Dante's inferno is the ruler of the Centaurs, and has a Centaur-like body.
380441: Iroas, God of Victory.text_posted: Not a Centaur - can tell by looking at the tail, which is clearly a bull's and not a horse's. This set up - with a bull's body and a human's torso and head - was actually the more popular way to depict the classic Minotaur in Italian Renaissance art. For example, the Minotaur in Dante's inferno is the ruler of the Centaurs, and has a Centaur-like body.

380442: Keranos, God of Storms.author: EvilDarkVoid
380442: Keranos, God of Storms.text_parsed:
At first glance, seems awesome. Extra draw every turn, with the only downside being that the draw will occasionally be a free Lightning Bolt (actually its a Lightning Strike, considering that this is Keranos). He's got the weakest p/t to cmc ratio for a god and is in the colors that will probably have the hardest time making him into a creature, so don't rely on that.

But wait. 5 cmc enchantment that draws an extra card every turn? Already exists in one of his colors (Honden of Seeing Winds). And for just one more mana you can get it in any color, and with other upsides like draw and damage, as well as no legendary clause (Staff of Nin). And there's actually less ways to abuse Keranos-the others work with Paradox Haze, while there's no way to make Keranos get you more than one card per turn cycle short of taking extra turns, which works with the other anyway.

I guess you could argue that he works well with Scry but most of the time you're just using that to make him closer to the consistency of the Honden. Which leaves the only advantage he has that he can become a creature-but with his mediocre stats for a god and poor colors for that, it's not exactly ideal.

At least he doesn't want you to have creatures like 11 of the other 14 gods do, including the mono blue and blue-black one...

380442: Keranos, God of Storms.author: Drewskithelegend
380442: Keranos, God of Storms.text_parsed:
This is really sweet but not terribly good for the common Izzet deck. I'm sure there are plenty of midrange decks that would love to play this guy I mean, damn.
-He's a 6/5 for 5 (sometimes)
-He does something very useful every turn regardless.
The best thing about him is how well he fits into that midrange tank category. Late game you want value out of your draws to play your large spells. Drawing lands is not optimal for most decks in this category, but this guy gives you an extra card for it! Sure, it might be a land card as well, but I'd rather draw 2 lands in 1 turn than 2 lands in 2 turns. He can additionally burn away blockers or just ping your opponent down even as an enchantment. While I think that he could have cost 1 less, he's still quite solid at 5 and is certainly one of the better gods. 4/5

@Bray you know what else forces you to reveal the card you "draw"? A couple of real turds come to mind: Dark Confidant,Gifts Ungiven,Fact or Fiction,Ad Nauseam,Enlightened Tutor,Mystical Tutor even stuff like Survival of the Fittest...
You know, cards that are either banned or extremely powerful in formats they can be played in.

380442: Keranos, God of Storms.author: Xenocide1337
380442: Keranos, God of Storms.text_parsed: Anyone who says this card is bad because it "reveals every card you draw" clearly doesn't understand red-blue. You you use blue scry effects to pick which card is revealed, to limit enemy knowledge and use the effect you want, simultaneously. Additionally, if you reveal a land, you draw an extra unseen card, which isn't really an advantage for the opponent. If you reveal a spell, you get to bolt! How great is that? Also, you are playing Blue-Red, meaning you're going to either go fast, control, or both. None of these strategies really care that the opponent knows your next trick. "Oh hey, look, it's a lightning bolt. Bolt ya with Keranos, then bolt ya with the bolt!" In that scenario it hardly matters that your opponent knew what spell you were playing five seconds before you played it. My only criticism of this guy is that his devotion effect might not activate often. However, since red has a lot of little creatures, rather than permanents that cost a lot of colorless filler, it may happen quicker than you'd think.

Honden of Seeing Winds is completely different from this. That card isn't indestructible. That card doesn't become a creature. That card doesn't deal 3 damage. Same with Staff of Nin. Remember that all you need to have out for this to be a creature is Dominus of Fealty.

380442: Keranos, God of Storms.author: leomistico
380442: Keranos, God of Storms.text_parsed:
Agree with whoever said that it needed to be "Reveal the first card you draw on each turn", something like the Miracles. Well, with some convolute wording it could have even been on every draw. Something like: "If you would draw a card, reveal it instead. If it's a nonland card Lightning Bolt then draw that card. If it's a land card, draw 2 cards." Note that it's not a endless loop, Blood Scrivener uses a similar template... Not that it's something that I'd like, I think that simply the miracle version would have been just perfect!
3.5/5

However, I wonder what it's up between the creative team and gods.
Onslaught Block: Karona, False God
Kamigawa Block: well, gods everywhere!
Ravnica Block: there were the Nephilim, that were some kind of god if I recall right.
Llorwyn Block: 10 demigods.
Zendikar Block: 3 gods that actually are some of the biggest and badassest (I know it's not actually a word...) creature in the whole multiverse.
Innistrad Block: Avancyn wasn't exactly a goddess, but almost. A lot of people prayed for her...
Theros Block: well...

380443: King Macar, the Gold-Cursed.author: Mode
380443: King Macar, the Gold-Cursed.text_parsed:
Flavor fix:

"Inspired Whenever King Macar, the Gold-Cursed becomes untapped, exile target artifact, creature or planeswalker.
If you do, put a colorless artifact token named Gold onto the battlefield. It has "Sacrifice this artifact: Add one mana of any color to your mana pool."

No "may"-clause:
It's a CURSE, for crying out loud. Where on earth is the downside if you MAY turn people into gold?
Midas would have been the happiest person if he could have kept drinking from his goblet and embrace his daughter.

Don't restrict the target to creatures:
It should affect anything physical. Midas couldn't turn whole landscapes into gold, but non-living objects (e.g. stones or food as in the original myth) should be affected as well. Planeswalkers should be affected by the touch just as any other being. Enchantment creatures are also affected this way.


Melvin bonus (as suggested by Ritokure):
Make him multicolored, so he can be a gold card.

380443: King Macar, the Gold-Cursed.author: StoicChampion
380443: King Macar, the Gold-Cursed.text_parsed:
This actually works perfectly as an "Inspire" ability. According to Myth, Midas was offered a reward for bringing Silenus back to Dionysus, and he asked that whatever he might touch should change into gold. After he was given this gift, he rushed home to put the ability to the test, choosing items outside and inside his house to be turned into gold. He didn't go into combat and strike a random foe, thus turning them to gold. He looked around the house for inspiration, and chose what would turn to gold.

As far as the may portion of the clause, it would have had to be either that, or it would have had to be "exile another target creature". Really, it should have been another permanent, or non-land permanent. He technically turned the river sands of the Pactolus to gold, when he relinquished his powers by cleansing himself in the waters.

380443: King Macar, the Gold-Cursed.author: Ferlord
380443: King Macar, the Gold-Cursed.text_parsed:
Macar is one of the best cards in Journey for draft.

Removal in limited is always valuable. Gild itself is quite valuable, since it can get rid of a creature pretty efficiently. A creature that has the capability to remove a creature each turn for free (essentially) is extremely valuable.

Macar just needs either one free attack step or a conduit of tapping. Weirdly, I think Theros has quite a few ways to tap your own creatures.

Once Macar is active, it's hard to stop it without removal. I guess that's a cop-out argument (similar to "dies to Doom Blade"), but as I said, removal is scarce and valuable in limited.

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: cyclicide
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed:
In my mind, this is the best general for Enchantress EDH to date.
1. He's an enchantment, so he triggers enchantress effects when cast.
2. Enchantments are hard to deal with, therefore great for enabling devotion.
3. Enchantress is very good at drawing cards; the no hand limit thing does a lot of good.
4. There are plenty of enchantments like Helix Pinnacle that serve as great mana sinks for all the extra mana Kruphix is gonna get you.
If only he were also white.

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: Shovel_The_Walk
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed:
While this is not the highest P/T God to hit the board, both abilities are insane for standard G/u Devotion or Bant Control strategies. For Devotion, multiple Monstrosity creatures can be activated, or X spells can be huge, and Mistcutter Hydra will be a giant, any wasted mana from Nykthos, Shrine to Nyx sticks around for later use, and Curse of the Swine can wipe a board. For no max hand size, Garruk, Caller of Beasts can overflow your hand.
Bant Control gets huge Sphinx's Revelation and Syncopate.
This would also compliment a Blue-based BUG Phenax Mill strategy, and this card has Commander written all over it.
4/5

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: DaLucaray
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed:
Dear Kruphix

Flavorfully, you are by far the best of the Gods. You know the secrets of Nyx. While they others are off squabbling with each other and now the mortals, you're chilling out on the edge of the world thinking about how to create and destroy Gods, twist and unravel reality, and whatever else goes on in your beautiful starry head. You are Blue and Green, my favorite combination of mana by far and probably the wisest.

Your card takes some thinking, though. Many other Gods, like Mogis, Purphoros, or Athreos, are big, splashy, and make you say "wow" when you see them. You, on the other hand, are subtle, crafty.

Kruphix the God, you are about infinite possibilities, opening your eyes to the world around you and the power within you. This card portrays that beautifully- I, the Planeswalker, under your guidance, can manage my resources and knowledge in ways other planeswalkers dream of.

Kruphix, you are by far my favorite God in all of Theros. No, all of fiction.

You rule.

Sincerely, your biggest fan

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: Sanctuary_Cat
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed: Kruphix makes a pretty crazy U/G general IMO. A little bit more subtle than Prime Speaker, but definitely a powerhouse. No maximum hand size might seem underwhelming, but this is U/G, the colors that love to ramp and draw cards. The mana sink ability benefits control, combo, or just slamming big fatties onto the table alike. In other decks as a part of the 99, he is still a worthy addition. At the worst, you get an indestructible Reliquary Tower, that you can Green Sun from your library, to just stockpile excess mana into for the rest of the game.

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: questionflanger
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed: Incredible commander! What a perfect merge between blue's craftiness and green's monsters. Run him with Squall Line and Hurricane to win with direct damage. Quicken + Gelatinous Genesis for a surprise army of mega ooze. Fable of Wolf and Owl + Ashnod's Altar to spam tokens, then refill your pool with them. Genesis Wave for 25? Yes, please. If you feel like having NO FRIENDS and making the world a bad place, you can run Vorinclex, Voice of Hunger and Jin-Gitaxias, Core Augur both! Vorinclex to double the mana going into your pool, Jin to draw you tons of cards. Too much fun. This is a real win for EDH from this set.

Someone at my playgroup said that this was a worse Omnath with reliquary tower slapped on to it

Great card, GUx players are happy for sure.

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: limitededition
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed: One of the coolest cards for Momir Basic to date. You can essentially skip a turn to double your mana output; if you aren't behind, that means you can skip your 7 and have a 50% chance to hit Emrakul, the Aeons Torn the following turn. If you're lucky enough to spike him AND dudes that have relevant activated abilities, (Kiku, Night's Flower comes to mind) you can mostly stay on curve, which is pretty insane if you think about it.

380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.author: limitsofmagic
380446: Kruphix, God of Horizons.text_parsed:
Should have called him Kruphix, God of G/U spells with X in the casting cost. I think it's time to dig out the old Power Sink and Untamed Might.

Edit: I just played this guy as a commander in multiplayer and I can say with some confidence that he is insane. I know Praetor's Counsel is a pretty awesome card already, but with this baby to cancel out its mana cost (several times over) it becomes absolutely ridiculous. Yes I will have my graveyard back thank you very much. And yes I will play half of it right away! p.s. I have about three counterspells now so don't bother trying to stop me.

On reflection I think he was given low power because the chances of getting and keeping his devotion up are better than pretty much any other god. Card draw, counterspells, land ramp and (albeit to a lesser extent than with black) regeneration and graveyard raiding is one hell of a formula for keeping plenty of cards on the board.

380448: Lagonna-Band Trailblazer.author: Mode
380448: Lagonna-Band Trailblazer.text_parsed:
A strictly better Yoked Ox with a useful heroic trigger seems crazy in limited.

She is also looking excellent with the Ordeals. Sample scenario without disruption:
T1: Starts out as an excellent blocker.
T2: Attacks as 2/6 after casting an Ordeal on it and is sure to survive combat.
T3: You might even cast another Ordeal on it, both go off* and on top of that you'll attack with a 5/8.
(*Which means you get to choose twice from the following:
10 life, Lightning Bolt, double Rampant Growth, Divination, or Mind Rot)

Obviously removal would hit you really hard in the nuts (especially on T3 before combat),
but the thought of it working out is still nice.
(You should have one mana left on that turn, so you might use that to cast an instant that protects her
(and gives her yet another +1/+1 counter) in response?)

380449: Launch the Fleet.author: LynxLegend
380449: Launch the Fleet.text_parsed: This might not be the most competitive card, but it is fun to play. Pulled one at the prerelease today, and it led to crazy stuff every time I used it. I like the flavor, honestly. I'm not sure if I like the fact that the tokens come in tapped and attacking. It's nice to have the extra damage when you need it, but it encourages you to target more creatures to get more value out of it, which in turn leaves you with fewer blockers. Overall, 4/5.

a Puritan of the 16th or 17th century.

380451: Lightning Diadem.author: Ferlord
380451: Lightning Diadem.text_parsed:
I personally don't see this as that bad of a card, at least in limited.

Like any valuable limited card, this provides multiple effects:

1. Can work as a kill-spell or a burn spell.
2. Boosts your creature.
3. Is an enchantment that can help other enchantment-based spells (Riptide Chimera, Kruphix's Insight, Floodtide Serpent, etc.)
4. Enables Constellation.
5. Enables Heroic.

don't get me wrong: This is FAR too overcosted, but if this card was also a cantrip, I'd expect people to take this early in the draft.

It's not quite Pillar of Flame, since it can't target players, but the instant speed is almost - almost - a fair trade-off for it at common.

Even so, I'd have preferred a Pillar reprint over this. Lack of instant speed never really hurt the Pillar that much against the decks it was needed for (i.e. dealing with Voice of Resurgence and Gravecrawler in Innistrad-RTR standard and Chandra's Phoenix once M14 dropped), and the same is pretty much true now.

@Opeth2010 - to me, this is rated so 'low' because we had Pillar of Flame which would have been, most of the time, a better option, and any red player will have had other instant-speed means of dealing with Mutavault. Shock was reprinted in the same set as the Vault, after all :P

380453: Mana Confluence.author: DaLucaray
380453: Mana Confluence.text_parsed:
@Continue

In Vintage you're playing a four color deck that plans on winning in less turns than you have fingers on one hand.

In the current standard, games are slower, and mana bases are much less wild. If I'm playing WU control, I know a Hallowed Fountain is going to, in an average game, hurt me less than this and be just as useful. In a tricolor you can utilize three shocklands, and use of this card is really up to how aggro you're going.

Nonetheless, there are a few archetypes that need this bad: two color aggro decks. See, shocklands were the only dual color lands in standard that can enter the battlefield untapped. Aggro decks need their mana as fast as possible, before the other guy can stabilize. Confluence is untapped, and will only deal marginally more damage than a shockland in all goes as planned. In a tricolor deck though, you can utilize three shocklands.

So all in all, a card is only as good as it's environment say it is.

Paying 1 life to tap this is irrelevant, when you have a deck that you know can win on turn 3-4 when it does it's thing. Being stuck with lands that can't pay for the cards in your hand is one of the worst things in the game. This land is insurance that you will always have the mana you need to get rolling, and believe me, in vintage/legacy, speed is everything.

I believe pretty much any of those formats, with decks that run 4 copies of City of Brass, they will run 4 copies of this too. Perhaps 4x Reflecting Pool also, to take advantage of lands that can produce any color, like this one.

380455: Master of the Feast.author: mooshimanx
380455: Master of the Feast.text_parsed:
This card is an absolute bomb in limited. Its out of the reach of most non-rare removal in the format, has a huge body and flies. The card penalty is mostly meaningless in limited because your opponent rarely can ever play a threat that will adequately respond to it quickly enough.

However, if you play this guy, you need to be sure and side him out if you have any reason to believe they're playing Pin to the Earth or Akroan Mastiff. You will almost always lose if either is active and unanswered.

380455: Master of the Feast.author: sweetgab
380455: Master of the Feast.text_parsed:
As a player very averse to giving his opponents easy card advantage, I believe in most cases a one-of Master of the Feast is worse for your deck than any reasonable card you can think of: an extra Swamp, a Herald of Torment, or a Bile Blight. While you can sometimes steal a game because they can't find something to deal with it in time, you come close to conceding to your opponent when they draw an extra card and then Hero's Downfall (or Unravel the AEther / Reprisal / what have you) it. At that point your chance of winning drastically diminishes, and it requires virtually no work from your opponent.

There are some exceptions of course. You could give it haste via, say, Hammer of Purphoros, then it becomes good because they now have to take 5 before they can get any card out of it. You could also protect it with Ajani's Presence or Gods Willing so they can't stop the damage. Another option is to sideboard it in against players who cannot remove it at instant speed. Without these considerations or support though, the Master is an very dangerous card to play in the maindeck, and can easily lose you more games than it wins you.

380460: Nightmarish End.author: Ferlord
380460: Nightmarish End.text_parsed:
Removal in Journey into Nyx is pretty inconsistent and situational. This is one of the few that can kill a creature "efficiently".

Look at all of the removal in Journey:

- Deicide/Other Enchantment Removal/Feast of Dreams: Only targets certain creatures.
- Dictate of Erebos: You don't choose what they sacrifice.
- Extinguish all Hope/Nyx Infusion: Similar to Deicide, but in the reverse manner.
- King Macar: Once he gets going, he's a free Gild. It's hard to get him started, though.
- Magma Spray: Good early game, but once you're facing 3/3s and 4/4s, you need something else to help kill it.
- Pharika's Chosen: Needs to block. Unless you give it flash, they'll see it coming from a mile away (which can be useful, but not for removal purposes).
- Reprisal: Pretty efficient and is better when dealing with big creatures than End, but doesn't take care of smaller utility creatures.
- Quarry Colossus: Doesn't remove it (though burying it can be better). Also costs and is reliant on mono white or two-colours to be effective.
- Riddle of Lightning: Why not just flip a freakin' coin?
- Silence the Believers: Woah! Actually good removal! It's just hard to get since it's a rare.
- Spiteful Blow: Not bad at all. Just a little slow and costly.
- Starfall: Was Punish the Enemy so broken?
- Banishing Light: Actually effective, few drawbacks. I'd go as far to say it's better than this.

Upon looking through the whole set, there are a few better options, but not many. Most of them has some kind of "fine print" you have to read before you can kill a creature.

I don't need to tell you this card is good, but I'll do it anyway. A great body for its cost considering other spiders (not too many solid 3-drops in that tribe, and certainly not many with 2 power), a graveyard engine AND a stapled-on Treasured Find? Plus, it just looks fantastic in the frame.

The immediate deck I want to build with this is a Spider Spawning tribal deck. Cycle Jungle Weaver, mill spiders with Mulch and Grisly Salvage and this fellow, then cast a Spider Spawning for sizeable numbers of tokens.

380463: Nyx-Fleece Ram.author: Continue
380463: Nyx-Fleece Ram.text_parsed:
Comparing to Ajani's Mantra:

PROS
- It's a creature! A creature with a huge butt, as it so happens; a 0/5 stops tons of threats.
- It's a sheep, and sheep are cute!

CONS
- It's a creature; that makes it vulnerable to more removal than just a simple enchantment.
- It's a sheep, and sheep are apparently weak. 0 power isn't doing it any favors, but at least it doesn't have defender.

Overall it's a better card than the Mantra, and is worth no less than a 4/5.

380463: Nyx-Fleece Ram.author: EvilDarkVoid
380463: Nyx-Fleece Ram.text_parsed:
Honestly? I've actually used this against aggro. Believe it or not, its not that good. As it has 0 power, it doesn't stop them from attacking every turn, and if they have more dudes than you have Rams (in standard aggro decks run a lot of cheap dudes, they're going to unless they've already lost) they can just attack in over and over. This card will stem the bleeding a bit but it won't actually let you beat aggro-you need a creature that can block to kill something and live or a lot of removal for that, and having Rams in your deck actually just reduces your chances of drawing a card that can actually win you the game. Also, I've never gained more than 4 life off a Ram, and I've played them turn 2.

Also, strictly sideboard card. You will regret it if you have these guys mainboard against control or even monsters.

380465: Oppressive Rays.author: Dabok
380465: Oppressive Rays.text_parsed:
At first I thought that this was a conditional, albeit much cheaper Arrest.
Now that I think more about it, maybe the 1 cmc does outweigh the fact that your opponent can do something to negate the effect.
Why? Because of opportunity cost. If your opponent decides to pay the cost of this, while having a limited mana pool and having cards in hand, chances are you've made him choose between utilizing the creature for the turn and casting a (or several other) spell/s. Which isn't all that bad for 1 mana.

Personally, I would just run a straight-up removal. But then again, I've never played around things like this too much to attest their effectiveness (for me, same type of card as Soul Tithe; in that there's a cost if your opponent wants their creature, which can be at your advantage or "not so much")

380467: Pensive Minotaur.author: Agent_Gold
380467: Pensive Minotaur.text_parsed:
Taking the idea of "What if... NOT smash?" one step further...

This minotaur is the sole survivor of the battle that took place here. Without a leader, he has no new orders, and so no reason to leave the battleground. As he has no companions left, he is probably experiencing feelings of regret. Perhaps not so extreme as mourning, but some degree of sorrow and loneliness.

And if he's been left here to himself long enough, the idea may finally occur to him that those creatures they fight might feel the same way he's feeling now.

Where will his thoughts go next? We may need to wait for a return to Theros to learn the answer to that...

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: Mode
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
She isn't terrible, but she pales in comparison to Athreos, God of Passage.

Yes, she's in the two most powerful devotion colors.
But the body is still very conditional. And her ability is both somewhat expensive and conditional.
Useful, yes. Especially if you are running her in a Constellation deck, since the Snakes are enchantments, too.

However, five mana for a death toucher is a lot, which is what she'll end up being more often than not.
Which makes her comparably slow, even slower (and more expensive inthe long run) than the gods with higher casting costs that grant you their abilities without investing any additional mana.

She would have been perfect if the activation cost was instead, and if there was a may-clause for putting the token onto the battlefield (so you could exile your opponent's creature cards without giving him tokens).
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_posted:
She isn't terrible, but she pales in comparison to [autocard]Athreos, God of Passage[/autocard].

Yes, she's in the two most powerful devotion colors.
But the body is still very conditional. And her ability is both somewhat expensive [i]and[/i] conditional.
 Useful, yes. Especially if you are running her in a [i]Constellation[/i] deck, since the Snakes are enchantments, too.

However, five mana for a death toucher is a lot, which is what she'll end up being more often than not.
Which makes her comparably slow, even slower (and more expensive inthe long run) than the gods with higher casting costs that grant you their abilities without investing any additional mana.

She would have been perfect if the activation cost was [(B/G)] instead, and if there was a may-clause for putting the token onto the battlefield (so you could exile your opponent's creature cards without giving him tokens).

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: mdakw576
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
It's obvious that if you always got the deathtouch snake it would be stupid. That's not the problem.

The real problem is why its ability doesn't feel like an "affliction". Wizards said that Pharika would be disease-related, and literally the only thing remotely disease-related on Pharika is the snake having deathtouch. If Pharika had something like "Creature you control have deathtouch", it would already feel way more disease-related than its current form. Power levels aside, Pharika is probably the worst god flavor-wise.

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: TheJord01
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
Ethan Fleischer, lead designer of JOU, just succinctly explained why Pharika doesn't give you tokens when she exiles from an opponents GY in his Reddit AMA today

"Consider what would happen if Pharika gave you tokens for exiling your opponent's creatures from their graveyard. You opponent attacks, you make a 1/1 deathtouch Snake, block their creature, which goes to the graveyard. You now have fuel to make another Snake, to block their next attacker. You opponent would be pretty helpless at that point."

That would have been an oppressive ability in Constructed, never mind limited.

@kirbster Read the rules for devotion. Hybrid mana only counts as 1 devotion to one colour. Creakwood Liege would only give 3 devotion to Pharika

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: Ike38
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
This god is being underestimated so much.... There are so many reasons to love her.

1) Get rid of some annoying creatures : Get rid of Chandra's Phoenix in graveyard and counter the ability of Scavenging Ooze before Ooze uses its activated ability so that Ooze could not grow and give your opponent's life. These two creatures are very annoying to go against if you have played Dredge before.

2) Mana sink : Super good against control. Your ability is at instant speed. You can decide whether to abrupt decay their detention sphere or get a little snake to attack them next turn.

3) Easy to transform : You just need only Jarad, Golgari Lich Lord and
Deathrite Shaman to transform her. 5/5 for 3 CMC. Does that sound similar with the other most expensive god (Thassa) ?

4) Good with combos : So far there are only 2 creatures that could generate enchantments almost infinitely (in the right deck) : Heliod, God of the Sun and her. The fact that Heliod, God of the Sun ability is way too expensive makes Pharika probably the only playable creature to generate infinite enchantments for your constellation mechanic and some other cool enchantment such as Sphere of safety or Ethereal armor.

I think she is playable in T2. What could I ask for more???

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: surewhynot
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
She's not BAD, let's get that out of the way. It's more that she's just boring and disappointing. We get it wizards, snakes are poisonous! Poison god likes snakes, cool...Doesn't mean that can be THE ONLY THING TO FOCUS ON with her. Honestly, her body, her disciples, and her ability all have to do with snakes, so it feels like a complete lack of effort and/or creativity went into her design. They could have done something with -1/-1 counters, deathtouch, tapdown abilities, etc.

It's also worth noting that Pharinka is the only god in the pantheon that does nothing unless you pay into it. Every other god does something passively. Boring snake issue aside, that's annoying. At the very least I'd have liked to see something like "Whenever another creature enters a graveyard from anywhere, exile it. That creature's owner puts a 1/1 black and green Snake enchantment creature token with deathtouch into play under their control"

Anyway, that's my two cents. Boring, lacking in flavor, and overall disappointing.

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: rainbownorth
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed: More solid than a lot of people are giving her credit for. Her cc is great for a 5/5 indestructible (eventually at least). Her last ability seems weak but in the right deck can wreak some terrible havoc. With combo cards like Nyx Weaver, Humbler of Mortals and Strength from the Fallen (although that last obviously has diminishing returns), she is pretty solid. More just a way to get a 2nd run out of your creatures for chump blocking than anything else, although the fact that the snakes are enchanments is a win too. I like her more for the fact that she's one of the more interactive Gods than anything else.

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: MarlKarx
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
I have a fantastic combo with this card. Deicide, Detention Sphere, Angelic Edict, Banishing Light, King Macar, the Gold-Cursed, Luminate Primordial and Merciless Eviction, not to mention countless counterspells.

I've read through the comments and found comment after comment trying to justify thi card, but it requires too much. One card from the opponents hand reduces it to dust. What is all the setup worth then? Pharika is by far the worst god. And probably even one of the worst cards claiming to be competitive in standard at the moment. It's the greatest dissapointment in golgari in recent standard. Why would you use pharika when you have Deathrite Shaman that can do the exact same, even better. It's a waste of space and an insult to the entire block. There is no justifying this card in standard.

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: OlvynChuru
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
@Drewskithelegend

Really? Pharika's ability is actually quite useful. Once you get a few creatures in your graveyard, the opponent isn't going to want to attack with any significant creature because you can just block with a 1/1 deathtoucher and kill it. One thing you could do with Pharika is use her with creatures that have flash, such as Boon Satyr. During your opponent's turn, if they attack, you get out a deathtouch snake, and if they don't, you cast a flash creature. Don't get so obsessed with your idea that Pharika's ability is never useful simply because there are some times when it isn't. Keep in mind that you will have creatures in your graveyard more often if you build your deck right. Think. Pharika is much, much more than just a possible 5/5 indestructible body.

@MarlKarx


Oh, so this card is bad because it dies to removal? While I'm not saying that you are unskilled, it's hard for me to respect your skill when you make arguments like that. Yes, Deathrite Shaman is a better card overall. However, Pharika's ability is better than all of the shaman's abilities combined. The ability to repeatedly get deathtouchers is insane. I have faced hordes of deathtouchers, and I can tell you that they are very, very nasty. Deathtouch is one of the most underrated abilities in Magic.

@Marlkarx

Ignoring that green canngive hexproof, two of those cost a bunch of mana and require it to be a creature, while this costs 3 and can do quite a bit of work before then, and if its a creature before hose get cast you can do quite a bit of work with a 5/5 indestructible. The shaman can only work once a turn bar shenanigans, it doesn't have a chance to become a 5/5 indestructible, and doesn't cycle out soon. The fact is they are both different cards so comparing them is as bad as "hurrr removal"

380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.author: DoorDie
380469: Pharika, God of Affliction.text_parsed:
Her ability is a fine test of human judgment and Magic mechanics/language. Give her an ability that can impact the opponent but improves their position, and watch the hate flow. In contrast, look at Dakra Mystic.

For one, the Mystic's ability affects both players at once. If Pharika's was somehow simultaneous, I think we'd be seeing less hate. The timing of Mystic converts it into an interesting mini-game as opposed to presenting an option that seems almost always bad.

For two, the Mystic's wording presents you with an explicit choice ("You may"), whereas the choice in using Pharika's ability is implicit. Imperative language exaggerates possible negative outcomes and stifles the imagination.

And three, the Mystic doesn't interact with the graveyard, while Pharika does when we've been spoiled already. We've been spoiled with library manipulation too; just not in Standard.

380473: Pin to the Earth.author: Hawk_of_Battle
380473: Pin to the Earth.text_parsed:
I just recently built an enchantments matter Simic deck using things like Eidolon of Blossoms, Kruphix, God of Horizons, and a bunch of other useful things to draw lots of cards and ramp into obscene amounts of mana. I got totally wrecked at the Journey to Nyx game day, as 3 of my 4 opponents were all running Master of Feasts and Desecration Demon.

Those 2 demons were pretty much the only things that I couldn't handle and everyone was running them. This card is the answer I need. Draws me cards if my Eidolons are out, stops Dec demon dead in his tracks, and keeps the Master sitting there drawing me extra cards which I can keep hold of whilst my opponent has nothing.

And it'll even stop a Polukranos, a Stormbreath Dragon (even when he's monstrous he's barely a threat).

Yeah, I can get behind this card.

380474: Polymorphous Rush.author: BolasEvilPlan
380474: Polymorphous Rush.text_parsed:
Mirrorweave 2.0, now with the ability to target opponent's creatures!

In reality, compare this card to mirrorweave:

Mirrorweave

- Costs less if using more targets

This card

- Doesn't turn your opponent's creatures into the targeted creature as well
- Can target legendaries.

Though I'd say mirrorweave is probably better overall, seeing as the type of deck you'd use it in involves lots of small tokens with 1 big card to mirrorweave, and the legendary targeting on this is situational value (You can use it as a 1-sided wipe which leaves your opponent with 1 creature of their choice I guess?)

380475: Prophetic Flamespeaker.author: Syrtees
380475: Prophetic Flamespeaker.text_parsed:
There seems to be some confusion about the general purpose of rarity these days.
Rarity simply means that you are more or less likely to pull it from a pack (and also, to a certain extent, thanks to New World Order, it also means the card may be more or less complex). What all of you are arguing is that a card (Bearer of the Heavens) that will only be used at the kitchen table should be pushed up in rarity because it's "epic", which in turn also means that you're pushing it farther away from the kitchen table players. Tournament players, the ones who are likely to go out of their way to buy useful mythics, will take one look at cards like Bearer of the Heavens and immediately dismiss it as unplayable. The kitchen table players would love to play that card, but they can't because their limited budget means that none of them pulled one from a pack because it's a mythic rare.
You're arguing that Bearer of the Heavens should be kept away from the players who will actually use it because it deserves to have that orange symbol to show everyone just how "epic" it is. That's unfair, neverminding the players who will be disappointed because this was the "mythic they pulled" (Maybe if they play it they'll realise just how good this card actually is).

Don't argue for Mythic because you see it as a status icon, think of the children.

380475: Prophetic Flamespeaker.author: SAUS3
380475: Prophetic Flamespeaker.text_parsed:
So awesome. I love the art and all of the abilities. He really loves to carry equipment (and I guess auras as well), so I threw him in my Tajic EDH deck. It is awesome that he gives red a way to draw cards, even if they are only usable for that turn.

I see some comments about his rarity. Some people think he should be rare because he is not epic enough, and others think he is good as a mythic because it limits circulation. To me, this card is amazingly epic.

You get to try to see what cards work with his doublestrike and trample. You get to try adding him into a red devotion deck. Maybe you have an aura deck and you use his ability to slowly add on more auras until you have an insane killing machine.

Another thing about being a mythic is that casual players will see it, know it's a mythic rare, and they will try to see why it's good, simply because its rarity says it is good.

This is a good mythic because it is cool, interesting, and also potentially competitive.

@evouga
I don't think this is vintage playable. Have you seen what vintage decks look like? They are actually stupid. Maybe legacy playable which is still super awesome, but at 3 mana, it will have a hard time finding space.

380475: Prophetic Flamespeaker.author: mooshimanx
380475: Prophetic Flamespeaker.text_parsed:
This is an undeniably great card that's undervalued at release because nobody has a clue whether a deck exists to support it - its a pushed card even without the exile ability. If I had to make baseless speculation, I think a deck will emerge and the card will get expensive, but it might not happen until the next block is out. Then again, he might never get good because he's too fragile for Modern (dies to Bolt) and too expensive for extremely aggressive decks.

However, its a very unassuming, and insanely fun card to play with. Opponents rarely seem to him as something more than a 1/3 with double strike, but you can get some totally bonkers hits out of this guy if you have any kind of pump. The first game I played after I put together a Flamespeaker deck I brained the opponent for 16 damage on Turn 3 by using my Elvish Mystic to get the Flamespeaker out on Turn 2, and then bloodrushing a Rubblebelt Maaka and a Ghor-Clan Rampager the next turn after the opponent declined to block.

And in casual settings, you usually don't worry much about getting to 7 mana. I mean, it's still hard, but it's not on the "if you reach this amount of mana you should be doing much more epic things...or have already lost".

Yeah, 7 mana is big, but all things considered, it's quite a balanced card. 5/6 is nothing to sneeze at (even though it's "beneath the curve") and the stabled removal is not weak either, it'll take your opponent several turns to take his creature back (normally)

I'm surprised no one has mentioned Strength from the Fallen yet. This card fits so freaking well with it, even adding to the graveyard before the effect goes off.

This card was tailor-made for graveyarding and constellation tripping. You get a chump blocker, sac it to fill the graveyard, but still keep (better) creature presence that also triggers abilities.

Good card, albeit very circumstantially good, but that's alright for a common.

It's pretty silly to expect a white removal spell to directly answer Stormbreath Dragon or Blood Baron. White has Celestial Flare and Elspeth, Sun's Champion to indirectly answer those anyway.

This is an awesome reprint from the days when flavor trumped symmetry and good high-power white creatures simply did not exist. The card itself is a beautiful example: balanced but powerful, then and almost 20 years later.

380482: Revel of the Fallen God.author: SlushyJones
380482: Revel of the Fallen God.text_parsed:
Yeah, I like tokens. But there are far better token makers in Green and/or Red than this card. A net of 8/8 power and toughness for 7 mana? Yeah, it's pretty good in that regard, but that's pretty slow compared to other token makers.

Now the key word in here is Haste. This changes the picture. This helps a bunch. You can attack with these guys as soon as you play them, so they can get past your opponent if they attacked all out. That's 8 damage there.

In relation to the other cards in the set, it can be great in a draft or something. If you add White, you can add Dictate of Heliod for 16 damage, or keep it just Red with Rouse the Mob. Buffing unexpected attackers can be a great thing.

380482: Revel of the Fallen God.author: DarthParallax
380482: Revel of the Fallen God.text_parsed:
Look, I want to like this card, as I love paying lots of mana to do things.

But guys....this seriously needs Trample.

Compare it to Titanic Ultimatum, which has a third color, and costs the same otherwise, and was a Rare in a Block with Mythic Rares.

Haste is good. Haste is very good. It ALMOST makes the card as good as 1.5 Ball Lightnings. 1.5 Ball Lightnings can be played by turn 4 though, this has to wait quite a bit longer.

4 2/2s with Haste and Trample = roughly a Damage Spell for 8 that threatens kill next turn if the opponent has no blockers or anything. Can still be countered, you can still be Wrath'd, but it becomes a more than reasonable finishing spell in the Xenagod Flavor Deck.


Do other cards in the Xenagod Deck have easy ways to give the 2/2 guys Trample? If so, then card is fine as is.
380482: Revel of the Fallen God.text_posted:
Look, I want to like this card, as I love paying lots of mana to do things. 

But guys....this seriously needs Trample. 

Compare it to [autocard]Titanic Ultimatum[/autocard], which has a third color, and costs the same otherwise, and was a Rare in a Block with Mythic Rares.

Haste is good. Haste is very good. It ALMOST makes the card as good as 1.5 [autocard]Ball Lightning[/autocard]s. 1.5 Ball Lightnings can be played by turn 4 though, this has to wait quite a bit longer.

4 2/2s with Haste and Trample = roughly a Damage Spell for 8 that threatens kill next turn if the opponent has no blockers or anything. Can still be countered, you can still be Wrath'd, but it becomes a more than reasonable finishing spell in the Xenagod Flavor Deck.


Do other cards in the Xenagod Deck have easy ways to give the 2/2 guys Trample? If so, then card is fine as is.

380485: Riptide Chimera.author: brunsbr103
380485: Riptide Chimera.text_parsed:
I've just noticed that the zodiac is represented in the form of enchantment creatures spread through Theros block, and this guy is totally pisces. Ares is Nyx-Fleece Ram, Taurus is Purphoros's Emissary, Gemini is represented by Mogis, God of Slaughter and Iroas, God of Victory. Cancer is Thassa's Emissary, and Leo is Nylea's Emissary. Virgo could be a couple of things, but I think Spirit of the Labyrinth makes the most sense. Eidolon of Rhetoric could be Libra, while Ephara, God of the Polis is clearly Aquarius. Courser of Kruphix is totally sagittarius, while Pharika, God of Affliction represents Ophiuchus. Next two is where it gets a little iffy, but Nyx Weaver is as close as I could find for scorpius, and capricorn could be Perplexing Chimera.


I could also be making something out of nothing, so take this comment with a grain of salt

380486: Rise of Eagles.author: Worldwalker1
380486: Rise of Eagles.text_parsed:
The eagles...
The eagles are coming!

Sorry, I just had to.

In essence, this fulfills much the same role as Join the Ranks. The differences are, while it is a sorcery and not an instant - and a more mana intensive one at that - the tokens are bigger, fly, and trigger all the enchantment love this block has, similar to how Join the Ranks' tokens triggered allies in Zendikar.

Add Scry to that, and I think this card certainly has a lot going for it.

Plus I really like the art - it looks like the eagles are flying into a Wrath of God.

Small creatures will die outright (notably Archetype of Courage) and everything that survives will become deadly but fragile. If you have more creatures, you will get through for big hits, and almost all blocks will require a trade. Everything just blows up. If two of those minotaurs are a Rageblood Shaman and a Felhide Petrifier...

It's a little odd that the Rollick will kill any satyr besides Wild Celebrants.

380489: Rotted Hulk.author: thevegetable
380489: Rotted Hulk.text_parsed:
@SAUS3
the art is 'wasted' for the same reason that all magic art is 'wasted': to make you look at the card; and this one is a pretty good example. vanilla, toughness-heavy creatures are easy to pass up, especially in black, but it's not a bad deal for B3, and if you're planning on a sengir or another notorious black 5 cmc attacker the next turn, it's nice to have something bottom-heavy around to block
@Pendulous
wood elementals are green elemental creatures made of wood, yes? take that wood, turn it into a ship, (against its will), let that ship sink into the ocean, let that wood brood a bit, and voila: one rotted hulk! (no longer green)

380491: Sage of Hours.author: MayhemDurden
380491: Sage of Hours.text_parsed: This card seems to be fun to play with, but I don't think it's going to affect standard's meta in any way; it'll probably see play in kitchen tables and other casual plays. Getting five +1/+1 counters on him isn't an easy task, mainly in standard since you don't have Blessings of Nature nor Increasing Savagery which would get him to 5+ counters with a single spell, but none of those spells grant him protection from any removal. In Standard you could try and add some counters on him with other creatures that can get +1/+1 counters (heroic / evolving creatures) then Bioshift the counters onto the Sage and maybe even swing before removing the counters to get another turn, but again, too many cards / too much effort to get an extra turn without really establishing a solid board position or finding ways to protect this guy. Of course, if you can get to turn 4 or 5 and play an Ajani, Mentor of Heroes and have the Sage on the BF with a couple of +1/+1 counters on it and/or a Vorel of the Hull Clade then it is game, but that would also be kinda hard to pull off.

380491: Sage of Hours.author: Drewskithelegend
380491: Sage of Hours.text_parsed:
Many spike-y EDH decks run a "take extra turns" card in them as their inexorable win condition. I play The Mimeoplasm and couldn't really find one to use myself...

Then this guy.

I run 3-4 */* creatures that are based on the size of the graveyard (Consuming Aberration,Lord Of Extinction etc.) and the later game is optimal for this, but I do have mill that hits fast and hard. I'm looking at

T1 swamp, sol ring
T2 island, Buried Alive sending Lord of Extinction,Sage of Hours,Stinkweed Imp or Phenax, God of Deception if I have a spell to reanimate him
Then you wait until graveyards become fairly large, through mill or other means. Playing a 75/75 sage ought to do it.

380491: Sage of Hours.author: Shamadruuu
380491: Sage of Hours.text_parsed:
It is actually surprisingly easy to get massive numbers of turns from this card, especially in my BUG +1/+1 counter ramp. With cards such as Renegade Krasis, Master Biomancer, and Corpsejack Menace, his 5 counter requirement becomes trivial.

Using cards like Give // Take and Vorel of the Hull Clade, in addition with Bioshift and Corpsejack Menace, he can be ramped up to massive numbers of counters with extreme ease.

If I do it properly, I can have Sage of Hours at over 5,000 counters when it enters, resulting in one thousand turns. While 5 - 10 extra turns is more likely, it isn't much of a step up to take thousands of turns. Using Master Biomancer, Corpsejack Menace, Vorel of the Hull Clade, and Kalonian Hydra (and an opponent who didn't want to forfeit), I've gotten into the range of millions of extra turns.

380495: Setessan Tactics.author: TPmanW
380495: Setessan Tactics.text_parsed:
I guess the automatic comparison is Prey Upon. This is double the cost and requires you to tap your creature. It is however instant speed which helps you mitigate that cost. It can also hit multiple creatures, scaling into a board wipe. The +1/+1 isn't much, but should let you trade up in the early game.
My verdict? These are totally different cards and will probably see play into different types of decks. Prey Upon is better removal, but this will see play in slower decks.

380495: Setessan Tactics.author: Petrified_Treefolk
380495: Setessan Tactics.text_parsed:
I for one think is this Green Gold! Everyone knows the power of Prey Upon! Cheap Green removal is a beautiful thing to see, now make a version that allows me to prey upon two, three (Or in my treefolk deck which has more land and mana then sense) ALL THE CREATURES. So after a horrible mass murder (Speaking of which, in the right deck, this kills two creatures for the same cost as Murder!) I'll be able to launch a powerful attack! Or maybe I could just find way to untap all my creatures and finish it there. This can be game ender, a game change, for that CMC you can't argue with the results.

The +1/+1 is just gravy on these buttery biscuits of goodness~

6/5, would run eight, will settle for 4

@TPmanW

I think your lacking some imagination when it comes to the possibility of this card. Prey Upon is better for a single target, but that's not what this card about. Casting without striving is a waste of this card completely. It's one of the few ways mono-green can do removal on larger scale, for a very low cost. If you pay four, or the same of the Wrath of God, you should be able to remove there three best creatures. Four Mana is a small price to pay for turning the tide of the battle.

Oh, and there the fact it triggers heroic ability but honestly the cards don't seem like the most impressive.

Does anyone remember Hornet Sting? one green mana, instant speed, for one damage to creature or player? That card has a rating of 3, because direct creature removal like this is so very rare in green, Lands, artifacts, enchantments (And often planeswalkers) all can be dealt with but with cards like these that really give green an extra touch.

I'm making this post because I really, really, really think this is a five star card. This card is amazing. This card can also work in a fast deck, I don't see why anyone think this card is slow by any means.

380496: Sightless Brawler.author: Dabok
380496: Sightless Brawler.text_parsed:
It's hard to evaluate the whole cycle of "negative but cheap bestows" they got going on in Journey into Nyx, but I do have to say that this one caught my eye as a good beater for white aggro. It's more fragile than your typical White Knight, but it packs 3 power.

And if you're already on mid-late, you can use the buff for yourself to get in those final points of damage that you need to score the win.
I may be idealizing the good scenarios on this one, but I have to say that I at least want to test him out.

4/5

380498: Sigiled Starfish.author: RedJaron
380498: Sigiled Starfish.text_parsed: People who dismiss this card haven't played against it.  0/3 is a substantial blocker, and scrying every turn is almost as good as drawing an extra card.

380498: Sigiled Starfish.author: Pinto331
380498: Sigiled Starfish.text_parsed:
Excellent, excellent 2 drop in limited. A roadblock to tons of early creatures and deck manipulation, what more can a control deck want?

Compare to Omenspeaker in the same slot. Omenspeaker will kill/trade with some creatures and nets you the scry immediately, better guaranteeing your 3rd or 4th land drops. Scryfish here will last longer into the late game however. At the prerelease he netted me my 7th land for a Scourge of Fleets on multiple occasions. The other downside to that is you will not be inclined to use him to chump as you might with Omenspeaker, and the delay from entering play to scrying means he's a bad late game draw. Still, there are few better turn 2 plays in Journey limited.

Or let me put it this way, he was so good I had multiple people dropping Banishing Light just to get rid of this. Yes, it is good.

380498: Sigiled Starfish.author: DmitryM
380498: Sigiled Starfish.text_parsed:
Best card ever printed. End of story. 99999/5, No need to print anymore cards.

Conditionally better than Thassa, god of the Sea solid casting cost, acts as if you play a scryland every single turn...

It's interesting to compare this to Nat Pagle in Hearthstone, it doesn't have a chance to draw an extra card, but it is a turn 2 reusable creature outside of most simple removal, forcing opponent to use 2 casting cost or higher removal to get rid of it.

It blocks rakdos cackler, firedrinker satyr, ash zealot...

WORSE, it can block AND scry at the same time, in the same format as triton tactics, which can slow down red substantially, into a place where they can no longer win before you wipe their board, or establish your own blockers/threats.

This card is definitely blue.

380498: Sigiled Starfish.author: SirLibraryEater
380498: Sigiled Starfish.text_parsed:
Ehhh.
Not a huge fan of scry. I guess if you're playing Flamespeaker Adept it's fine, but I wouldn't play this too often.
My problem with scry is that if you scry 1 once in a turn and put the card on top, any and all scry 1 effects you would play for the rest of the turn is totally useless. If scry 2+ was a thing in Theros block, I'd be a lot happier with this. But as it stands, it's not my favorite card ever.
*INCOMING BUTTHURT RESPONSES*

380500: Skybind.author: Cloudchaser.Kestrel
380500: Skybind.text_parsed:
In magic my favorite thing - and yes I know it should be drawing cards or something useful, but my favorite thing is having two glimmerpoint stags enter the battlefield every end step and exile each other. When I first saw this card I thought it was my new favorite card. Not broken - it's spaced out from end step to end step, it costs five mana - but I began imagining entire enchantment armies crashing in and out of play. Safe from harm for most of the turn, triggering other constellations when they enter. It was beautiful.

I built a deck around it in my head as I came back from school on the bus. It made me so happy.

And then I read the card again "nonenchantment stood out this time.

I'll still use this card. It has utility - and I can bounce my enter the battlefield triggers - but it lends itself to an unthemed deck. a deck that fights against itself.

I think that as an evolving game new cards need to take risks, I'm disappointed this one couldn't.

380500: Skybind.author: Dabok
380500: Skybind.text_parsed:
The 5 mana cost is rather troublesome at first. But now that I think about it, it's actually not that bad since it triggers when you put it into play itself (compared to your typical enchantment mechanic engine which doesn't trigger when it enters play), so I guess that therein lies a justification for the rather hefty cost.

Other than that, it looks like it's a rather fun card to build around. It always is with bounce effects. Although with this one you'll have to play with enchantments and bounce non-enchantments, which feels kinda weird (and challenging) for deck-building.

380500: Skybind.author: Ansem717
380500: Skybind.text_parsed:
Target nonenchantment permanent? Wait... I can flicker lands? O_O Reuse any scry trigger from the temples. Flicker any Vivid land to restore the charge counters.

WAIT!

I CAN FLICKER PLAINSWALKERS. Could go hefty into a negative ability for a plainswalker to spare it the loyalty counters, I guess. That ''until end of turn'' clause is iffy. Although if I flash in an enchantment to flicker my plainswalker during an opponents turn after they declared it as an attack... I can just imagine Sarkhan The Mad running and hiding when he sees an onslaught of little creatures coming to attack him.

Overall, I really like this card. The concept of a delayed flicker is alright, but usually we're focusing on creatures for delayed flicker. This card widens the playing field to anything except enchantments. Sure I can still flicker Angel of Serenity or Thragtusk, but I could also restore the charge counters on Sphere of Suns and Tangle Wire, or I could continuously exile cards with Jester's Scepter...

Although, an interesting one will be to use this with Apocalypse after casting about two Oblivion Rings on my own stuff and saving my land with Skybind.

380500: Skybind.author: Divoda
380500: Skybind.text_parsed:
This with any enchantments that have flash such as Feral Invocation or Boon Satyr. Maybe with some auramancers in the deck.

Situation like this:
Enemy attacks with creature you can't afford to block you cast feral invocation on that creature and then target that creature with skybind. Exile creature until end of enemie's turn, feral invocation goes into your graveyard then you play an auramancer to return it to your hand.

Now if you play something big you can put feral invocation on that to make it even bigger while exiling the same creature so it can't block.

380500: Skybind.author: Manaklash
380500: Skybind.text_parsed:
This does pretty interesting things with Gift of Immortality and any Sac Outlet...

Step 1: Cast Gift of Immortality on a Creature with a sac outlet.

Step 2: Cast Skybind and bounce w/e you want until the next End Step.

Step 3: Sacrifice the creature enchanted with Gift of Immortality. It will return to the battlefield immediately. Gift of Immortality will return in the End Step. Stack the triggers so that the Creature that was exiled by Skybind returns first. Bounce it again until the NEXT End Step with the Gift of Immortality trigger.

Step 4: Repeat

You can keep any single opposing threat constantly suspended in exile indefinitely, only blinking in briefly during each end step.

Bonus points if you enchant an Enchantment Creature with Gift of Immortality for twice the triggers.

380501: Skyspear Cavalry.author: Dabok
380501: Skyspear Cavalry.text_parsed:
A rather big mana-cost. Speaking of which, I do like to compare her with Serra Angel.
Unbuffed, they do the same amount of damage. In terms of toughness however, this is more fragile, but more rewarding when buffed because of double-strike. This is less active in the field (without vigilance, you have to decide to either defend or attack, with Serra Angel, you have more freedom to do what you want) also.

So, all-in-all, Serra Angel still gets the upper hand in general, but I think that this card has it's own charm, in that you feel the "high risk, high reward" much more than the safer, but more sure, Serra Angel.
I think it remains a rather solid card, especially if you take in consideration that she belongs in a set where buffing creatures up is the norm rather than the exception.

4/5

380502: Solidarity of Heroes.author: Judgemaster_Rolan
380502: Solidarity of Heroes.text_parsed:
This is an awesome instant that only costs 2 mana! And since it's an instant that costs 2 or less, I like to bring out one of my favorite artifacts to combo with this: Isochron Scepter.

Double the number of +1/+1 counters every turn for 2 mana?! Yeah, it's that mean. And the way Strive is written means that you can ignore it if you cast a spell with Strive without paying its mana cost. Then you can target anything and everything that you want to!

To really capitalize on this, You can use a Forgotten Ancient, or from this set Nature's Panoply (imprinted onto a second Isochron Scepter). This should allow you to put at least 4 +1/+1 counters on any creature each turn. Then you just need to play Sage of Hours (who, with Heroic, can get at least 6 counters per turn.) and the rest of the game becomes a solitaire match!

380503: Spawn of Thraxes.author: Shivan_Raptor
380503: Spawn of Thraxes.text_parsed: While at first he may not seem like an extremely competitive pick, think for a moment about the idea of what cards we all sometimes consider good. Anything that requires more than a turn to get the most out of is considered sub-par, at least if something similar to it exists with faster effects. Forgestoker Dragon doesn't do anything the turn he resolves. Yeah hes cheaper but he sits there as a target for a turn. I'll concede that Stormbreath Dragon is better, but again he usually a "one-turn" kinda card. Maybe Spawn of Thraxes here is a 3-star card, but I do have a soft spot for him, partially because he was my best win-con at draft, but more so because he has potential to be a strong card in a properly built deck i.e. pure-red mid-late range, if that is even a thing.

380507: Squelching Leeches.author: BolasEvilPlan
380507: Squelching Leeches.text_parsed:
Compare to nightmare:

Nightmare

+ Flying
+ Is a unicorn
+ Has Been around since alpha
+ Less black required (Though doesn't really count seeing as you only run them in mono-black, unless you run Urborg, Tomb of Yawgmoth and you want to use these guys for some reason)
- Costs 2 more

Leeches

+ Costs less
- No flying
- Leeches are ugly

So discounting all the trollish arguments, it's really a case of would you pay 2 more for flying on your fatty?

380512: Supply-Line Cranes.author: Dabok
380512: Supply-Line Cranes.text_parsed:
On a flavor perspective, I really love how some magic cards explain the role of certain things on the place that they live in. I don't have many other examples in mind, but there are lots of magic cards that do this. It is especially appealing to me, since these aren't your typical "Akroan X" or "Setessan Y", which, just by the name itself, already has an indication on what role they have.
But Vanilla sounding names, plus a flavor text that situates and fits them in the block that these cards are in, is just sweet.

380514: Temple of Epiphany.author: StrayWanderer
380514: Temple of Epiphany.text_parsed: I was very excited when they released the first spoiler of a scry land, oddly giving us better mana fixing than our beloved Ravnica shock lands did in standard, at the cost of entering tapped. Then with the release of Mana Confluence, I understood the incredible range of color shenanigans available in standard at the moment - it is so vast that five color is viable, but really only effective as a splash on a three color. Decks can logically run only two white mana symbols in their deck as long as they wish to scry over having a mana a turn earlier. My only worry is that mono/dual colored aggro decks will be able to blow slightly slower decks out of the water, but there is always a price to mana fixing, entering tapped with deck control is not too high of a price for me.

380516: Tethmos High Priest.author: Mode
380516: Tethmos High Priest.text_parsed:
Too bad he can't return creatures up to a converted mana cost of 3, which would have made it a Heroic Unearth.
That would make him really super interesting for constructed.
(He's also in bolt range and has no form of protection, so he can easily be dealt with.)

However, the ability is still quite interesting. Casting Spells with Rebound (e.g. Emerge Unscathed, Distortion Strike) can turn his ability into some considerable card and board advantage.

Creatures you can sacrifice immediately like Saffi Eriksdotter, Children of Korlis or Martyr of Sands should be great.
Other simply good cards like Voice of Resurgence, Tarmogoyf or Snapcaster Mage (which in turn would allow you to cast another spell) will do a nice job, too.

Also he's a Cleric, so in Legacy there's Rotlung Reanimator and a good amount of Clerics that will gladly turn into martyrs (two mentioned above), particularly Dark Supplicant.
380516: Tethmos High Priest.text_posted:
Too bad he can't return creatures up to a converted mana cost of 3, which would have made it a Heroic [autocard]Unearth[/autocard].
That would make him really super interesting for constructed.
(He's also in bolt range and has no form of protection, so he can easily be dealt with.)

However, the ability is still quite interesting. Casting Spells with [i]Rebound[/i] (e.g. [autocard]Emerge Unscathed[/autocard], [autocard]Distortion Strike[/autocard]) can turn his ability into some considerable card [i]and[/i] board advantage.

Creatures you can sacrifice immediately like [autocard]Saffi Eriksdotter[/autocard], [autocard]Children of Korlis[/autocard] or [autocard]Martyr of Sands[/autocard] should be great.
Other simply good cards like [autocard]Voice of Resurgence[/autocard], [autocard]Tarmogoyf[/autocard] or [autocard]Snapcaster Mage[/autocard] (which in turn would allow you to cast another spell) will do a nice job, too.

Also he's a Cleric, so in Legacy there's [autocard]Rotlung Reanimator[/autocard] and a good amount of Clerics that will gladly turn into martyrs (two mentioned above), particularly [autocard]Dark Supplicant[/autocard].

380519: Thoughtrender Lamia.author: Araes
380519: Thoughtrender Lamia.text_parsed: I like this things ability, but it's just badly placed.  At 6 cmc 2 colored, you should really be getting finishers or at least power/toughness that reflects the point of the card.  With this much cost, the P/T is under curve, and the ability enters so late that few folks would ever include it.  It's Uncommon too, so it should already be better than common cards at cost.  Sadly, there are cards that make you discard better (Academy Raider, Ashioks Adept, Liliana's Reaver) and many better black cards of 6 cmc.  The only thing I can say for it is there's no better, semi-low rarity, 6 cmc black creature in this set - but you'd probably still be better just using another card, as it's a power that nearly demands a significant part of the deck support it.

380520: Tormented Thoughts.author: Continue
380520: Tormented Thoughts.text_parsed: @Purplerooster: We don't really get instant speed discard nowadays.
380520: Tormented Thoughts.text_posted: @Purplerooster: We don't really get instant speed discard nowadays.

380520: Tormented Thoughts.author: Mode
380520: Tormented Thoughts.text_parsed:
"Wish this was an instant to get some extra value in response to removal, but nonetheless this is pretty interesting. You'll need to be sacing a creature with 3 power or more to get the same card advantage out of it as Mind Rot." Purplerooster

"@Purplerooster: We don't really get instant speed discard nowadays." Continue

That doesn't mean we can't get any.
I think this would have been a good candidate for instant speed discard.
It's conditional since you need a creature for it to work, and if you decide to cast it on your opponent's turn to make him discard that one card he drew, you will in a way have to suffer card disadvantage as well, since you could otherwise have cast this spell in response to an opponent's removal.

So yes, this would have been awesome at instant speed.
At Sorcery speed, I think this could have passed for as well.

I might still try it with cards like Sheltering Ancient or Vexing Devil, though.
There should be a couple of fun limited plays happening with Master of the Feast as well.

380522: Triton Shorestalker.author: Mode
380522: Triton Shorestalker.text_parsed:
Remember the Prowl mechanic from Lorwyn?
Because this is the perfect one-drop to activate it.

Blue Prowl cards: Thieves' Fortune (great topdeck control), Latchkey Faerie (powerful cantrip flyer), Notorious Throng (for a token-generating Time Warp), Knowledge Exploitation (potent sideboard card).
Black Prowl cards: Auntie's Snitch, Earwig Squad, Stinkdrinker Bandit (which works perfectly with unblockable creatures), Morsel Theft, Noggin Whack.
Other good two-drop Prowl enablers: Inkfathom Infiltrator, Invisible Stalker.
Bonus points: Oona's Blackguard for discard, Sygg, River Cutthroat for extra cards.

There's also potential use for Fish and Ninja decks. Although regarding the latter, I feel like we'll get a functional reprint Ninja eventually when we get back to the glorious Ninjutsu mechanic.

Also, am I the only one that finds it unfitting that this card has an assassination flavor text?

380524: Underworld Coinsmith.author: Blind_At_Heart
380524: Underworld Coinsmith.text_parsed:
Been excited about this card since it was spoiled. This card will be a killer in Limited and should see Standard play.

In any WB deck in Limited you have so much reach it's ridiculous. In any board stall where you have more life than your opponent you will be able to drain them for 2-3 on their turn, then drain the rest on your turn to kill them. If you have this guy and your opponent is at less than 6 life (given you have more than that) they're probably just dead.

In Standard this will be insane for the same reason and because you can design your deck to be heavy with enchantments to keep your life total higher than theirs. This guy adds 2 devotion to Athreos and if you remember Tidebinder Mage being played because it adds UU to your devotion, this guy will definitely be a better 2 drop for the a WB deck because of the reach.

And imagine two of these guys in play at the same time?
Brain Maggot, gain 2. Banishing Light, gain 2 and swing...
What an outstanding card.

380524: Underworld Coinsmith.author: Mode
380524: Underworld Coinsmith.text_parsed:
The clay masks are fine, too. But I still see a missed flavor opportunity.

This guy seems to be at least partially based on the Greek Underworld ferryman Charon, who was payed a coin to ship the dead across Acheron.

This block just so happened to introduce a certain kind of artifact tokens named Gold.

Why would they not take advantage of these perfectly convenient odds and make him interact with these Gold tokens in some way?

   "Whenever a creature is put into a graveyard from the battlefield, that creature's controller chooses one exile that    creature, or put a colorless artifact token named Gold onto the battlefield. It has "Sacrifice this artifact: Add one    mana of any color to your mana pool."

(Obviously it wouldn't be a Constellation card anymore, and the flavor text wouldn't fit anymore either.)

The concept for this Conestellation card is nice, but damn,
it irks me that these coins would be "shaped from clay and funerary masks."

380525: War-Wing Siren.author: Dwst
380525: War-Wing Siren.text_parsed:
Question: does the heroic ability trigger if the Siren is a target of an constellation from an enchantment creature already on the battlefield triggered by casting an enchantment that does NOT target the Siren?

Example - Oakheart Dryad is in play, constellation effect is when an enchantment comes into play under your control, target creature gets +1/+1. Siren is in play. If another enchantment is cast and the Siren is chosen as the target of the constellation effect, does she get a +1/+1 counter?

I suspect the answer is "no," but had to ask if it triggers when she becomes a target while a spell is being cast. She surely does get extra counters from Nature's Panoply and Satyr Grovedancer

380528: Worst Fears.author: Cyxics
380528: Worst Fears.text_parsed: In a Grixis Commander deck, this card can create an interesting combo between itself, Radiate, and Eye of the Storm(or any other consistent spell copier). Radiate makes this card target as many players as you want to (unless hexproof?) and Eye of the Storm gives you an easy way to recast those cards. This combo is not resilient and can be easily played around, of course, but it at least provides you with an interesting win condition - the puppet master.
